data.title: New York Angler Achievement Awards Program
data.meta_description: The New York Angler Achievement Awards Program features a number of opportunities for anglers to receive awards and prizes for their amazing catches.
data.text:
Angler Award Category

The Angler Award recognizes anglers who catch any of the 40 eligible fish species that meet or exceed the minimum qualifying lengths established for that species. Anglers receive a species-specific Angler Achievement Award sticker â€“ can you collect all 40!?

Entry Rules

Eligible Species and Qualifying Lengths

Entry Rules

Fish must be taken during their respective open season by angling or ice fishing in New York State waters in accordance with New York State Fishing Regulations. Fish showing signs of foul hooking (hooked other than in the mouth), gill nets, tampering or foreign objects will be disqualified. Bowfishing entries are not eligible.

Entry Form: Qualifying fish must be entered on the official entry form. All applicable portions of the entry form must be completed. Entry forms must be received within 30 days of the catch.

Submitting Photographs:

A side-view photograph that shows the entire fish (angler with the fish is encouraged).

The fish should also be photographed next to a ruler, measuring tape, or an object of known size (e.g., fishing rod, tackle box, etc.).

Information provided on the entry form and associated photographs become the property of the DEC and may be used for promotional purposes.

Angler Award and Youth Angler Award Entry Requirements

The fish must be one of the 40 species designated under the Angler Award and Youth Angler Award Categories.

The fish must be measured from tip of nose to tip of tail.

The fish must meet or exceed the minimum qualifying length.

The number of stickers awarded annually will be limited to one sticker per angler per species.

State Record Category Entry Requirements:

The fish must be one of the 39 species designated for State Record consideration.

Fish must be weighed on a certified scale by the owner or employee of the business where the scale is located. Certified scales can be found at post offices, supermarkets, and bait shops. Fish weighed on personal handheld scales will not be accepted.

Weighing must be observed by one witness other than the scale owner or business employee.

The fish must exceed the previous record by at least 1 ounce to qualify as a new state record (see current State Records).

Fish must be kept for the purposes of being weighed on a certified scale (see b. above) and examined by a DEC Fisheries Biologist.

The fish must be identified and examined by a DEC Fisheries Biologist prior to any cutting of the fish or removal of entrails. If caught during the weekend, keep fish on ice (do not freeze) after weight certification. Contact the appropriate DEC Regional Fisheries Office on the next business day.

Fish fed or otherwise grown with the intention of breaking a state record will be disqualified.

The DEC Bureau of Fisheries reserves the right to reject any Angler Achievement Award Application on the basis of erroneous species identification, improper handling, illegal fishing methods, evidence of tampering or foreign objects, or inability to adequately document any of the circumstances relating to the catch.
